text.p: JULY Close * Support * Resist * RSI14 * MA10 * MA30
Thursday's sharp rally in London coffee futures has left technical analysts wondering if the market would continue its upward pattern or start reversing downwards.

Traders called the market to open $40 higher. The second-month July contract rose by nearly 20 percent or $412 per tonne to a high of $2,670 at one stage on Thursday in a frenzied buying led by roasters.
Trevor Neil, senior technical analyst at Union CAL Futures, said Thursday's explosive run left a big chart gap at between $2,262 and $2,360 basis July.
The volume was twice the normal size, the price range was very wide and prices closed near their highs.
"But the big gap was left. Technicians have to decide whether this is a continuation or a reversal pattern...can be either," Neil said.
"The important thing is how the market behaves concerning this gap. If it is left open, it will be a 'measuring' gap indicating that this present run should extend to $2,800."
"However, the closing of the gap would tell us that the top has been seen and the market will suffer a severe sell-off," he added.
Neew York's arabica coffee futures broke the $3.00 a lb mark on Thursday as the broad-based buying frenzy continued.
July arabicas shot up to a life-of-contract high of 318.00 cents, the highest price in two decades, before closing at 314.80 cents, up 19.25 cents -- or more than six percent -- on the day.

"We are seeing history happen," said Christian Wolthers, vice president of Miami-based importer Blaser & Wolthers Specialty Coffee Trading Co. "We've not seen a market move like this without frost, drought or any other kind of tragedy. It is a clear situation of short supply for demand."
In other news, world consumer coffee stocks stood at 10 million bags in April, up from 8.80 million in March and 1.1 million bags higher than April 1996, UK trade house E D & F Man said on Friday.

It said stocks, reflecting some of the impact of high coffee exports earlier this year, were now 2.4 million bags above the all-time-low in December 1996, Man said in its April/May coffee report. --Jalil Hamid, London newsroom +44 171 542 4985
